description: From French cavalcade, from Old French cavalcade, from Old Italian cavalcata, from cavalcare (“to ride on horseback”), from Medieval Latin caballicō, from Vulgar Latin caballus (“horse”). Doublet of chevauchee.

entries.meaning: (collective) A procession of riders, vehicles, ships, etc.
A trail ride, usually more than one day long.
(by extension) An often dramatic series or chain of events or things.
examples: As soon as I visited this website, a cavalcade of dialog boxes started to appear on my screen; that's when I realized my computer was infected with a virus.

verbs.description: cavalcade (third-person singular simple present cavalcades, present participle cavalcading, simple past and past participle cavalcaded)

entries.meaning: To move as part of a series or group, such as marchers in a parade or snow in an avalanche, especially in large numbers or in a chaotic or dangerous fashion
examples: Great numbers of horse were still cavalcading, but  […]
